claim: Archaeologists spend most of their time excavating historical sites.

supporting.text: Excavation is a fundamental part of archaeological fieldwork, as it allows researchers to uncover and study artifacts and structures directly.

attacks.text: Excavation is a fundamental part of archaeological fieldwork, as it allows researchers to uncover and study artifacts and structures directly.
Modern archaeologists spend significant time on lab analysis, documentation, and preservation, not just excavation.
Many archaeological projects focus on surveying or non-invasive techniques like ground-penetrating radar rather than excavation.
Even when excavation occurs, it often represents less than 30% of total project time due to permit processes and post-excavation work.
Some high-profile excavations (e.g., Pompeii) do dominate researchers' careers for decades.

supporting.text: Archaeologists spend significant time on lab work, analyzing artifacts, and writing reports, which often takes more time than excavation itself.

attacks.text: Archaeologists spend significant time on lab work, analyzing artifacts, and writing reports, which often takes more time than excavation itself.
Excavation is the most visible and resource-intensive part of archaeology, often requiring months or years of fieldwork.
While excavation is time-consuming, post-excavation analysis and reporting can take even longer due to the meticulous nature of artifact preservation and documentation.
Some archaeological projects focus on re-examining existing collections, requiring little to no excavation time at all.

supporting.text: Field seasons are often dedicated to excavation, which can last for months, making it a major time commitment for archaeologists.

attacks.text: Field seasons are often dedicated to excavation, which can last for months, making it a major time commitment for archaeologists.
Excavation is only one phase of archaeological work; post-excavation analysis, lab work, and report writing often take longer than the excavation itself.
Many archaeologists specialize in non-excavation roles like archival research, remote sensing, or conservation, which do not involve significant excavation time.
Some archaeological projects focus on survey or documentation rather than excavation, meaning no time is spent digging.
Even in excavation-heavy projects, permits, funding acquisition, and community engagement can dominate the timeline rather than physical digging.

supporting.text: Many archaeologists work in cultural resource management, which involves surveys and documentation rather than extensive excavation.

attacks.text: Many archaeologists work in cultural resource management, which involves surveys and documentation rather than extensive excavation.
Excavation is still a significant part of archaeology, especially in research-oriented projects.
Even in cultural resource management, excavation is often required when surveys identify significant sites.
Many archaeologists specialize in excavation-heavy subfields like classical or biblical archaeology.

supporting.text: Excavation is a highly visible and resource-intensive activity, often requiring permits and logistics that dominate an archaeologist's schedule during fieldwork.

attacks.text: Excavation is a highly visible and resource-intensive activity, often requiring permits and logistics that dominate an archaeologist's schedule during fieldwork.
Many archaeologists spend significant time on lab work, analysis, and documentation post-excavation, which can take years compared to the shorter excavation phase.
Fieldwork seasons are often limited to specific times of the year due to weather or funding constraints, reducing the total time spent excavating annually.
Some archaeologists specialize in non-excavation work like archival research or digital reconstruction, which requires no excavation time.
Permit acquisition and logistics are often handled by administrative staff or project managers, not the archaeologists themselves.

supporting.text: Academic archaeologists spend considerable time teaching, publishing, and applying for grants, reducing the time available for excavation.

attacks.text: Academic archaeologists spend considerable time teaching, publishing, and applying for grants, reducing the time available for excavation.
Field archaeologists, who are not in academia, spend the majority of their time excavating sites.
Even academic archaeologists often conduct fieldwork during summers or sabbaticals, balancing teaching and excavation.
Funding for excavations is often tied to academic output like publications, forcing academic archaeologists to prioritize non-excavation work.
